revision.text:
{{pov|date=February 2017}}
{{Reformation in Kerala}}
'''Kallumala Samaram''' (Stone Necklace Protest) is an agitation or social revolution by [[Pulayar]] community that took place at [[Perinad]] and nearby villages such as Cherumoodu, [[Kanjavely]] etc. in, [[Kollam district]] on October 24, 1915.
The agitation is also known as [[Perinad]] Lahala or [[Perinad]] Mutiny. It enjoys a significant position in Kerala history.
== History == The agitation was a sudden uprising against the upper class's dictum to the minority castes to not use the public road, denying the right to education, prohibiting entry to temples and denying women to wear gold or metal ornaments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/thiruvananthapuram/Communist-Party-of-India-revives-Perinad-Lahala-memories-to-fight-extremism/articleshow/54670958.cms|title=Communist Party of India revives Perinad Lahala memories to fight extremism - Times of India|access-date=2016-10-05}}</ref>
The agitation intensified by December-end and a meeting was convened under the chair of [[Ayyankali]] on December 21, 1915 at Plavilapurayidom, Cherumoodu, near [[Perinad]] where women belonging to Pulaya community threw away the ''Kallumala'' (ornaments made out of stone and woods) and proclaimed that they will only use gold or metal ornaments. Kallumala's were chains of beads worn by their ladies as a symbol of slavery and inferior caste status.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://socialscienceijksubdist.blogspot.in/2010/01/kallumala-samaram.html|title=kallumala samaram|website=socialscienceijksubdist.blogspot.in|access-date=2016-10-05}}</ref>
Through this agitation the oppressed class fought the caste elites by breaking their chains to win the right to wear ornaments.
During pre-independence era women from lower castes in Kerala faced severe unfathomable oppression. There were strict diktats regarding dress codes and ornaments and there was even taxes to be paid to erstwhile [[Travancore]] kings for covering their breasts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/200-years-on-nangelis-sacrifice-only-a-fading-memory/article5256145.ece|title=200 years on, Nangeli's sacrifice only a fading memory|last=Surendranath|first=Nidhi|date=2013-10-21|newspaper=The Hindu|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X|access-date=2016-10-05}}</ref>
== See also == # [[Caste system in India]] # [[Ayyankali]] # [[Caste system in Kerala]] # [[Channar revolt]] # [[Ooruttambalam]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:History of Kollam district]] [[Category:Indian caste system]] [[Category:1915 in India]] [[Category:People from Kollam district]]

{{Infobox Ethnic group |group = Koreans in Paraguay
재파라과이 한인
''Jae Paraguai Hanin''
''Coreanos en Paraguay'' |population = 5,205 (2011){{citation|url=http://www.mofat.go.kr/webmodule/htsboard/template/read/korboardread.jsp?typeID=6&boardid=232&seqno=334627&c=&t=&pagenum=1&tableName=TYPE_DATABOARD&pc=&dc=&wc=&lu=&vu=&iu=&du=|title={{asiantitle|재외동포 본문(지역별 상세)|||a}}|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade|date=2011-07-15|accessdate=2012-02-25|page=171}} |region1 = [[Asunción]] |pop1 = 4,540 |ref1 = |region2 = [[Ciudad del Este]] |pop2 = 528 |ref2 = |region3 = [[Encarnación, Paraguay|Encarnación]] |pop3 = 89 |ref3 = |region4 = [[Pedro Juan Caballero, Paraguay|Pedro Juan Caballero]] and others |pop4 = 48 |ref4 = {{citation|chapter=La presencia coreana en Paraguay|title=Corea del Sur: una puerta para el Paraguay|first=Zulma|last=Espínola González|publisher=Banco Central del Paraguay|date=2002|accessdate=2008-10-02|url=http://www.bcp.gov.py/gee/investman/zeg/koreapyzeg.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030724165749/http://www.bcp.gov.py/gee/investman/zeg/koreapyzeg.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2003-07-24}} |langs = [[Paraguayan Spanish|Spanish]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[English language|English]]{{citation|url=http://www.asian-efl-journal.com/conference_book_2007.swf|last=Choi|first=Jinny|chapter=English as an International Language: its power, influence, and effect on Koreans living abroad — A comparative study on language maintenance and language shift among Koreans in Paraguay and Koreans in the United States|date=May 2007|title=The Inaugural Global EIL Congress — English as an International Language: Setting the Standards|publisher=The Asian EFL Journal|accessdate=2008-10-02}} |rels = [[Christianity]] |related = [[Korean diaspora]] }} '''Koreans in Paraguay''' formed one of the earliest [[Korean diaspora]] communities in [[Latin America]]. However, they were always overshadowed by the larger Korean communities in neighbouring [[Brazil]] and [[Argentina]], and since the late 1990s, their population has fallen significantly.{{citation|last=Lesser|first=Jeffrey|chapter=Asians in South America|url=http://www.everyculture.com/South-America/Asians-in-South-America.html|title=Countries and their Cultures|editor1-last=Ember|editor1-first=Melvin|editor2-last=Ember|editor2-first=Carol R.|publisher=Macmillan Library Reference|date=23 May 2001|isbn=978-0-02-864950-4|accessdate=2008-10-02}}{{citation|url=http://www.okf.or.kr/data/status_SA.jsp|title={{asiantitle|재외동포현황 - 중남미||Status of overseas compatriots - Central/South America|a}}|publisher=Overseas Korean Foundation|date=2005|accessdate=2008-09-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414101829/http://www.okf.or.kr/data/status_SA.jsp|archivedate=2009-04-14|df=}} ==Migration history== The first Korean immigrants to Paraguay came from [[Busan]] on a two-month journey by sea to [[Buenos Aires]] and then overland to [[Asunción]], finally arriving on 22 April 1965.{{citation|last=Park|first=Chae-soon|chapter=La emigración coreana en América Latina y sus perspectivas|title=Segundo Congreso del Consejo de Estudios Latinoamericanos de Asia y de Oceania|publisher=Latin American Studies Association of Korea|publication-place=Seoul|date=2007|url=http://www.lasak.or.kr/CELAOfiles/papers/Session3/Park%20Chae%20Soon%5BSession3-2%5D.pdf|accessdate=2008-09-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217010906/http://www.lasak.or.kr/CELAOfiles/papers/Session3/Park%20Chae%20Soon%5BSession3-2%5D.pdf|archivedate=2012-02-17|df=}}{{citation|url=http://www.abc.com.py/2004-10-03/articulos/137351/piden-a-nuestro-pais-eliminar-visas|periodical=ABC Digital|publication-place=Paraguay|title=Piden a nuestro país eliminar visas|date=3 October 2004|accessdate=2008-10-02}} Exact numbers of migrants are difficult to calculate because Paraguay offered on-the-spot visas to all foreigners, and did not distinguish between those who came to settle in the country as opposed to those who intended to remain only temporarily; 120,000 Koreans arrived in Paraguay between 1975 and 1990, according to official figures, but many migrated onwards to Brazil, both legally and [[illegal immigration|illegally]]. Paraguay's 1982 census showed 2,700 Koreans in Paraguay, but this was believed to have undercounted the actual population by as much as an order of magnitude.{{citation|date=December 1988|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+py0047)|chapter=Immigrants|title=Country Study: Paraguay|publisher=Library of Congress|publication-place=United States of America|accessdate=2008-10-02}} By 1999, [[South Korea]]'s [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade (South Korea)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade]] estimated that 10,428 Koreans resided in the country, but by just two years later, that figure fell by more than 40% to 6,190. The population continued to decline after that, though less sharply; {{asof|2009|lc=on}}, Koreans in Paraguay had fallen to the fifth-largest group of Koreans in Latin America, and 24th largest in the world.{{citation|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade |publication-place=South Korea |year=2009 |accessdate=2009-05-21 |url=http://www.mofat.go.kr/consul/overseascitizen/compatriotcondition/index6.jsp?TabMenu=TabMenu6 |title={{asiantitle|재외동포현황||Current Status of Overseas Compatriots|a}} |ref=CITEREFMOFAT2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101023213104/http://www.mofat.go.kr/consul/overseascitizen/compatriotcondition/index6.jsp?TabMenu=TabMenu6 |archivedate=2010-10-23 |df= }} Between 2009 and 2011, the population remained roughly stable. Of the 5,205 South Korean nationals or former nationals in Paraguay in 2011, 499 had become [[Paraguayan nationality law|Paraguayan nationals]], the vast majority (4,641 persons) had permanent residency, 16 were [[international student]]s, and 49 had other kinds of visas. ==Business and employment== The early Korean migrants who settled in Paraguay engaged in a variety of agricultural and commercial work, including [[beekeeping]] and [[door-to-door]] sales of imported clothing. By the early 1980s, many were involved in importing consumer electronics as well. Some also opened [[convenience store]]s in poorer neighbourhoods; they gained attention for remaining open through the [[siesta]], unlike many of their competitors. The second generation have largely moved away from manual labour or small retail business, and entered into the liberal professions, such as medicine, law, pharmacy, architecture, and accountancy. ==Language and education== Koreans in Paraguay opened their own school in 1972, the [[Colegio Coreano del Paraguay]] (파라과이한국학교), to provide cultural and language education to their youth. It is located in the [[San Vicente (Asunción)|San Vicente]] neighbourhood of Asunción.{{citation|periodical=ABC|url=http://archivo.abc.com.py/2004-07-03/articulos/119921/encuentro-infantil-de-danzas-espanolas-en-colegio-coreano|date=2004-07-03|accessdate=2011-03-13|title=Encuentro infantil de danzas españolas en colegio coreano}} A [[Korean American]] [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian]] church opened another school, the Colegio Presbiteriano Cerritos, in [[Villa Elisa (Paraguay)|Villa Elisa]] (in the Asunción metropolitan area) in 1992.{{citation|url=http://www.abc.com.py/nota/atracan-una-escuela-a-50-metros-de-comisaria/|title=Atracan una escuela a 50 metros de comisaría|periodical=ABC|first=Higinio|last=Ruiz Díaz|date=2011-03-05|accessdate=2011-03-13}}{{citation|url=http://www.cerritos.edu.py/somos.html|title=Quienes somos|publisher=Colegio Presbiteriano Cerritos|accessdate=2011-03-05}} Little [[language shift]] is observed from Korean-dominance to Spanish-dominance among members of the Korean community in Paraguay, including those born locally; this contrasts sharply with the rapid shift from Korean-dominance to English-dominance among [[Korean American]]s, especially of the second generation. Many Koreans in Paraguay send their children to study in universities in the United States and Europe; as of 2007, there were also roughly 100 Paraguay-born Koreans studying at universities in [[South Korea]]. They typically view English, rather than Spanish, as the most prestigious and economically important language to learn. ==Religion== Korean Christian missionaries are active among indigenous communities in [[Alto Paraná]] department.{{citation|url=http://www.abc.com.py/nota/coreanos-entregaron-viveres-a-los-indigenas/|periodical=ABC|title=Coreanos entregaron víveres a los indígenas|date=2010-12-23|accessdate=2011-03-13}} Korean churches in Ciudad del Este include Jardín del Dios and Iglesia de la Asamblea de Dios.{{citation|title=Religiosos coreanos prohíben estacionar vehículos frente a su iglesia|periodical=Diario CDE|date=2011-01-07|accessdate=2011-03-13|url=http://www.diariocde.com.py/v3/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1544:religiosos-coreanos-prohiben-estacionar-vehiculos-frente-a-su-iglesia&catid=36:tennis&Itemid=72}}{{citation|url=http://www.abc.com.py/nota/iglesia-coreana-dona-equipos/|periodical=ABC|title=Iglesia coreana dona equipos|date=2011-02-26|accessdate=2011-03-13}} ==Notable People== * Daniel Chung, sports journalist * Daiana Cubilla Lee, Miss Paraguay 2009 runner-up * Alice Park, Miss Paraguay pageant participant and model * Yolanda Park, journalist and TV host for TV Canal 9 ==See also== *[[Paraguay–South Korea relations]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{ko icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.parschool.or.kr/ Colegio Coreano del Paraguay] {{Korean diaspora}} {{Immigration to Paraguay}} [[Category:Asian Paraguayan]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Paraguay]] [[Category:Korean Latin American]] [[Category:Overseas Korean groups|Paraguay]] [[Category:Immigration to Paraguay]]

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Kurds in Finland |image = |population = more than 13,300 |region1 = [[Uusimaa]] |pop1 = 7,022 |ref1 =<ref name="Tilasto"/> |region2 = [[Southwest Finland]] |pop2 = 2,458 |ref2 =<ref name="Tilasto"/> |languages = [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]] |religions = [[Sunni Islam]] |related =[[Iranian people]] }} '''Kurds in Finland''' refers to [[Kurdish people|Kurds]] living in [[Finland]]. In 2017 there were 13,327 [[Kurdish language|Kurdish speakers]] in Finland<ref name="Tilasto">{{cite web|title=Kieli iän ja sukupuolen mukaan maakunnittain 1990 - 2017|url=http://pxnet2.stat.fi/PXWeb/pxweb/fi/StatFin/StatFin__vrm__vaerak/statfin_vaerak_pxt_031.px/?rxid=2362652d-c9b9-42f2-8a0b-95ac5bef4fec|publisher=Tilastokeskus|accessdate=30 August 2017|ref=Tilasto}}</ref> and the number of ethnic Kurds is probably higher.
==History== Some of the Finnish Kurds originate from [[Turkey]] and [[Iran]], but most of them have come from [[Iraq]], where they started arriving from in the 1990s as [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|UNHCR]] quota refugees. Kurds make up the majority of Iraqi immigrants to Finland.<ref name="EOD">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Diasporas - Volume II|date=2005|publisher=Springer|isbn= 0306483211|pages=1004–1010|ref=EOD}}</ref> After [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]] gained ground against the [[Peshmerga]] in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] the Finnish Kurds organized protests against ISIL.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hjelt|first1=Yrjö|title=Suomen kurdit osoittavat mieltään terroristijärjestö Isisiä vastaan|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/suomen_kurdit_osoittavat_mieltaan_terroristijarjesto_isisia_vastaan/7429730|publisher=Yle Uutiset|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref> According to the chairman of Finnish-Kurdish friendship association several dozens of Finnish Kurds had left to Syria and Iraq in order to fight against ISIL.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ijäs|first1=Johannes|title=Arvio: Jopa kymmeniä lähtenyt Suomesta kurditaistelijoiden riveihin|url=http://www.kotimaa24.fi/artikkeli/arvio-jopa-kymmenia-lahtenyt-suomesta-kurditaistelijoiden-riveihin/|website=Kotimaa24|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
==Culture== Finnish Kurds speak several different dialects of Kurdish, the largest of which are [[Sorani Kurdish|Sorani]] and [[Kurmanji Kurdish]]. Kurmanji has more speakers worldwide, but Sorani is the most spoken Kurdish dialect in Finland. It is likelly that there are more ethnic Kurds than there are those who speak it as a first language. For example, some of the Kurds who originate from Turkey speak [[Turkish language|Turkish]] rather than Kurdish. There are several different Kurdish organizations in Finland, many of which have direct or undirect connections to political parties in Iraqi Kurdistan.<ref name="EOD"/>
Almost all Finnish Kurds are Muslim and in the Iraqi Kurdistan, where the most Finnish Kurds hail from, most Kurds are [[Sunni islam|Sunni Muslim]]. Kurds are not however usually very active in religious life, since many of them have leftist and secular political background.<ref name="EOD"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Kurdish diaspora}}
[[Category:Ethnic groups in Finland|Kurds]] [[Category:Kurdish diaspora|Finland]]

page.title: List of graphic art works with LGBT characters

revision.comment: /* List of works */copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; url trimming of identifying info per[[WP:LINKSTOAVOID]] and [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|Citation Style]], replaced: emperor H → Emperor H
revision.text:
{{about||webcomics|List of webcomics with LGBT characters|animated works|List of animated works with LGBT characters}} This is a '''list of graphic art works with LGBT characters'''. This list includes [[gay]], [[lesbian]], [[bisexual]] and [[transgender]] fictional characters in comic series, newspaper strips, [[graphic novel]]s, and [[manga]]. ==History== In the 1950s, American comic books, under the [[Comics Code Authority]], adopted the Comic Code which, under the guise of preventing "perversion", largely prevented the presentation of LGBT characters for a number of decades.{{cite book|last=Booker|first=M. Keith|title=Encyclopedia of Comic Books and Graphic Novels [2 volumes]: [Two Volumes]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YbkJ0QJrEZ8C&pg=PA246|accessdate=2 January 2015|date=2010-05-11|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9780313357473|pages=246–}} Within the Japanese anime and manga, ''[[yaoi]]'' is the tradition of representing same-sex male relationships in materials that are generally created by women artists and marketed mostly for Japanese girls {{cite book|last=Publishing|first=Here|title=The Advocate|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RGUEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA86|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=2003-10-14|publisher=Here Publishing|pages=86–}} while the genre known as ''[[Yuri (genre)|yuri]]'' focuses on relationships between women. ==List of works== {{see also|LGBT themes in comics|List of webcomics with LGBT characters}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%" ! Year(s) ! Title ! Character(s) ! Classification ! Notes ! Country |- | 1963–2015 | ''[[Uncanny X-Men]]'' | [[Northstar (Marvel Comics)|Northstar]] | Gay | First appearance: ''Uncanny X-Men'' #120 (1979).
Northstar was the first openly gay superhero in the [[Marvel Comics]] universe.{{cite book|last=Misiroglu|first=Gina|title=The Superhero Book: The Ultimate Encyclopedia of Comic-Book Icons and Hollywood Heroes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BlKKx5aOSukC&pg=PT112|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=2012-04-01|publisher=Visible Ink Press|isbn=9781578593958|pages=112–}} | United States |- | 1970–present | ''[[Doonsbury]]'' | [[Andy Lippincott]] | Gay | First appearance: 1976.
Andy Lippincott was the first openly gay character to appear in a mainstream comic strip. | United States |- | rowspan="3" | 1974–1975 | rowspan="3" | ''[[Thomas no Shinzō]]'' | Thomas Werner | rowspan="3" | Gay | rowspan="3" | Set in a German boys boarding school, the story relates how, after Thomas' suicide, an upper classman, Yuri, finds a love letter Thomas wrote to him, and then meets a new student, Eric, who looks just like Thomas.{{cite book|last=Duggan|first=Anne E.|title=Queer Enchantments: Gender, Sexuality, and Class in the Fairy-Tale Cinema of Jacques Demy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=brjDAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA115|accessdate=31 December 2014|date=2013-10-15|publisher=Wayne State University Press|isbn=9780814338544|pages=115–}} | rowspan="3" | Japan |- | Julusmole Bayhan ("Juli" or "Yuli") |- | Eric Fruehling |- | 1979–2008 | ''[[For Better or For Worse]]'' | Lawrence Poirier | Gay | In 1993, Lawrence Poirier's [[coming out]] generated controversy, with readers opposed to homosexuality threatening to cancel newspaper subscriptions.[http://cartoonician.com/the-lynn-johnston-interview/ The Lynn Johnston Interview, ''Hogan's Alley'' #1, 1994] See also: [[For Better or For Worse#Lawrence comes out|''For Better or For Worse''#Lawrence comes out]]. | Canada |- | 1983–2008 | ''[[Dykes to Watch Out For]]'' | Mo Testa | Lesbian | Mo is a semi-autobiographical representation of the creator [[Alison Bechdel]] who started the strip in because she wanted to see representations of her life that were not available in the media at the time.{{cite book|last=Elledge|first=Jim|title=Queers in American Popular Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qp52mROzDMYC&pg=RA1-PA83|accessdate=1 January 2015|year=2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9780313354571|pages=1–}} | United States |- | 1987–present | ''[[JoJo's Bizarre Adventure]]'' | [[Dio Brando]] | Bisexual | In an interview in 2007 for Eureka magazine, Hirohiko Araki responded "...women, men--Dio can go with either." to a question about Dio's sexuality.http://jojo.wikia.com/wiki/Interview_Archive | Japan |- | rowspan="2" | 1988–1997 | rowspan="2" | ''[[Hen (manga)|Hen]]'' | Chizuru Yoshida | Bisexual | rowspan="2" | Chizuru is a buxom high school girl who has a tendency to manipulate the people around her. At the start of the story, she has a boyfriend and is also shown seducing a male teacher for the purpose of sleeping in his house. She becomes smitten with Azumi, a petite, innocent and shy girl from the same school. Though Chizuru initially hesitates to act on it, she manages to convince Azumi to join her in a lesbian film, in which both girls are the lead actresses and their characters are the ones who fall in love. Chizuru constantly uses this as an excuse to attempt to be intimate with Azumi, such as inviting her to hug and kiss for the purpose of rehearsing the film. Though Azumi tends to be uncomfortable with her advances and often gets away from her without doing what she wants, Azumi eventually becomes aware of her feelings and reciprocates them. | rowspan="2" | Japan |- | Azumi Yamada | Lesbian |- | 1988–2008 | ''[[Marvel Comics Presents]]'' | Jessie Drake | Trans woman | First appearance: ''Marvel Comics Presents'' #150 (1994). Jessie came out as a transgender girl in ''Marvel Comics Presents'' #151 and is the first openly transgender character in the Marvel Universe. | United States |- | 1989–2011 | ''[[List of Archie Comics publications#V|Veronica]]'' | [[Kevin Keller (comics)|Kevin Keller]] | Gay | First appearance: ''Veronica'' #202 (2010). Kevin was first eyed by Veronica who did not realize he was gay. He has since become a part of the gang.{{cite web|url=http://archiecomics.com/characters/kevin-keller/|title=Kevin Keller |publisher=Archie Comics}} | United States |- | rowspan="12" | 1989–2015 | rowspan="12" | ''{{sort name|The|Sandman|dab=Vertigo}}'' | [[Desire (DC Comics)|Desire]] | Genderqueer | Desire is the personification of desire itself. Desire is both male and female, because the character represents everything someone might desire. Desire is called "sister-brother" or "sibling" by his/her siblings and "uncle-aunt" by his/her nephew Orpheus. | rowspan="12" | England |- | [[List of The Sandman characters#Alex Burgess|Alex Burgess]] | rowspan="2" | Gay | rowspan="2" | In "Sleep of the Just", the 1st issue of ''[[The Sandman: Preludes & Nocturnes|Preludes & Nocturnes]]'', Alex Burgess and Paul McGuire are lovers who spend decades together. Alex is the son of Roderick Burgess, the man who attempts to imprison [[Death (DC Comics)|Death]] but imprisons [[Dream (comics)|Dream]] instead. After the death of Roderick, Alex inherits the ownership of the Order of Ancient Mysteries and continues keeping Dream as his prisoner. Later, Alex passes the order on to his boyfriend Paul. Eventually, Dream escapes and puts Alex in an eternal nightmare. In ''[[The Sandman: The Kindly Ones|The Kindly Ones]]'', Dream dies five years later, which causes Alex to wake up from the nightmare, asking for Paul. |- | [[List of The Sandman characters#Minor mortals|Paul McGuire]] |- | [[List of The Sandman characters#Foxglove|Foxglove (Donna Cavanagh)]] | rowspan="3" | Lesbian | rowspan="3" | Donna and Judy are lovers. After Judy dies, Donna changes her name to Foxglove{{cite book |last=Gailman |first=Neil |date=June 1996 |title=''[[Death: The Time of Your Life]]'' #3 |publisher=[[DC Comics]] |page= 8}} and starts a relationship with Hazel. Foxglove and Hazel have a child, Alvie, the result of one heterosexual encounter by Hazel. In "24 Hours", the 6th issue of ''[[The Sandman: Preludes & Nocturnes|Preludes & Nocturnes]]'', Judy, in a 24-hour diner, tries to talk to her girlfriend Donna on the phone, but Donna's mother does not approve of Judy and hangs up on her. Bette, the diner waitress, secretly wrote a story where the two girls are married to young men. Eventually, Judy dies as a victim of [[Doctor Destiny|John Dee]], who uses Dream's ruby to force everyone in the diner except himself to commit suicide. In ''[[The Sandman: A Game of You|A Game of You]]'', Donna, now called Foxglove is living with her girlfriend Hazel. Hazel is pregnant because she cheated on her girlfriend with a gay man. Foxglove has a nightmare in which the deceased Judy blames her for her death. In the 2nd issue of the spin-off mini-series ''[[Death: The High Cost of Living]]'', Foxglove has her first gig as a singer. She sings about the deaths of Judy and Wanda. Hazel, still pregnant, and [[Death (DC Comics)|Death]] are present in the audience. In another spin-off mini-series, ''[[Death: The Time of Your Life]]'', Foxglove and Hazel are raising Alvie. Foxglove has become a famous musician. While travelling on tour, Foxglove cheats on Hazel multiple times, and one of her partners, Véronique, publicly outs Foxglove as lesbian without her consent. When making a deal with Death, Foxglove offers to give her life so that Alvie may live, but Boris (who promised to care for Foxglove) does it in her place. In the end, Foxglove, Hazel and Alvie stay together as a family. |- | [[List of The Sandman characters#Minor mortals|Judy]] |- | [[List of The Sandman characters#Hazel McNamara|Hazel McNamara]] |- | [[List of The Sandman characters#Minor mortals|Chantal]] | rowspan="2" | Lesbian | rowspan="2" | Chantal and Zelda are a lesbian couple introduced in ''[[The Sandman: The Doll's House|The Doll's House]]''. They dress in white and collect spiders. |- | [[List of The Sandman characters#Minor mortals|Zelda]] |- | [[List of The Sandman characters#Wanda|Wanda]] | Trans woman | She is a transgender woman featured in ''[[The Sandman: A Game of You|A Game of You]]''. She is Barbie's best friend. She is unable to visit the Dreaming together with Thessaly, Foxglove and Hazel because the magic ritual used only allows passage for people with biologically female bodies. She dies in the storm caused by Thessaly's magic and is buried as "Alvin", her former identity. Wanda is last seen, along with [[Death (DC Comics)|Death]], in Barbie's dream. |- | [[List of The Sandman characters#Cluracan|Cluracan]] | Gay | Cluracan is a member of Faerie folk. In ''[[Season of Mists]]'', when a number of immortals visit Dream to bargain for the ownership of Hell, it is shown that Cluracan is gay, as he sleeps with a male Egyptian priest. When the visit is over, Cluracan complains that he is tired of one-night stands and wonders if the Egyptian priest will write to him. |- | [[Corinthian (comics)|Corinthian]] | Gay | The Corinthian is a nightmare created by [[Dream (comics)|Dream]]. He has two additional mouths in place of his eyes, which he covers with sunglasses. In ''[[The Sandman: The Doll's House|The Doll's House]]'', he goes AWOL from the dreamscape and becomes a [[serial killer]] who invites men to have sexual relations with him, then murders them. Corinthian then removes the eyes of their victims and eats them using his eye-mouths. Neil Gaiman has stated that the Corinthian is homosexual in ''The Sandman Companion'', wherein the first Corinthian consumed eyes only of boys. The second Corinthian is featured with a boyfriend as written by Caitlin R. Kiernan in the Dreaming.{{Citation | last = Irvine | first = Alex | author-link = Alexander C. Irvine | contribution = The Dreaming | editor-last = Dougall | editor-first = Alastair | title = The Vertigo Encyclopedia | pages = 64–65 | publisher = [[Dorling Kindersley]] | place = New York | year = 2008 | isbn = 0-7566-4122-5 | oclc = 213309015}} |- | [[Harun al-Rashid]] | Bisexual | Caliph Harun al-Rashid, the king of Baghdad featured in "Ramadan", a short story in ''[[w:The Sandman: Fables & Reflections|The Sandman: Fables & Reflections]]'', has a wife and a harem with women and young boys. |- | 1990–1994 | ''[[Yu Yu Hakusho]]'' | Miyuki | Trans woman | Miyuki is a character from both the manga and the anime. She is a trans girl and a member of the Demon Triad, a group of demon warriors that work for the Toguro Brothers. Her trans status is discovered in her fight against Yusuke.{{cite web|url=http://www.comicvine.com/miyuki/4005-46449/|title=Miyuki (Character) |publisher=Comic Vine}} | Japan |- | 1991 | ''[[Hothead Paisan|Hothead Paisan:Homicidal Lesbian Terrorist]]'' | Hothead Paisan | Lesbian | Created by [[Diane DiMassa]], Hothead Paisan's presentation was cathartic to lesbians, but so graphically violent that the strip was banned in Canada.{{cite book|last=Charney|first=Maurice|title=Comedy: A Geographic and Historical Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Og4ntxFQP2cC&pg=PA129|accessdate=1 January 2015|year=2005|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780313327148|pages=129–}} | United States |- | rowspan="4" | 1991–1997 | rowspan="4" | ''[[Sailor Moon]]'' | [[Dark Kingdom#Kunzite|Kunzite]] | rowspan="2" | Gay | rowspan="2" | Zoisite and Kunzite, both powerful generals who work under Queen Beryl from the Dark Kingdom are an openly gay couple in the series.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sara-ronceromenendez/kissing-cousins-viz-wont-_b_5353859.html|title=Sailor Neptune and Uranus Come Out of the Fictional Closet|first1=Sara |last1=Roncero-Menendez|work=The Huffington Post|date=21 May 2014|publisher=}} | rowspan="4" | Japan |- | [[Dark Kingdom#Zoisite|Zoisite]] |- | [[Sailor Uranus]] (Haruka Tenoh) | rowspan="2" | Lesbian | rowspan="2" | Haruka and Michiru are in a relationship. |- | [[Sailor Neptune]] (Michiru Kaioh) |- | 1992–1996 | ''[[Fushigi Yûgi]]'' | [[List of Fushigi Yûgi characters#Nuriko|Nuriko]] | Genderqueer, bisexual | Nuriko is one of the seven Celestial Warriors of Suzaku. She is introduced as "Kang-Lin", a woman in Emperor Hotohori's harem who has the power of [[superhuman strength]].''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 4: "The Seven Constellations of Suzaku" Nuriko is in love with Hotohori and at first considers Miaka her rival for his love,''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 5: "Dangerous Love" but Nuriko and Miaka soon become friends.''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 18: "Only You" Miaka discovers that Nuriko is [[sex assignment|assigned male at birth]],''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 7: "The Aimless Heart" then the evil duplicate of Miaka from the mirror [[outing|outs]] Nuriko to Tamahome and Hotohori without her consent.''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 8: "A Dark Invitation" Throughout the series, Nuriko is often referred to as a man. However, she claims to have the soul of a woman. Because of this, unlike Tamahome and Hotohori, Nuriko is allowed to open Miaka's shirt to treat her wounds, after the encounter with Miaka's evil duplicate.''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 9: "Awakening Memories" Nuriko decides to use a male identity and clothes when helping Miaka in her quest to find the remaining Celestial Warriors.''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 12: "Reaching Out" Afterwards, Nuriko asks Miaka to use Suzaku's wish-granting powers to transform her into a woman.''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 34: "The Final Embrace" Miaka fully intends to fulfill Nuriko's request, but soon discovers that she is unable to make any wishes. All seven Celestial Warriors are needed to summon Suzaku, but Amiboshi is a spy posing as Chiriko.''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 35: "The Treacherous Tune" Eventually, Nuriko chooses to cut off his long hair and stop dressing as a woman, to protect Miaka full-time as a man.''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 46: "Maelstrom of Fear" Nuriko states that even though as a woman she is in love with Hotohori, as a man he is in love with Miaka.''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 47: "Watching You Always" Nuriko dies at the hands of Ashitare, a beast-like Celestial Warrior of Seiryū.''Fushigi Yûgi'', chapter 48: "Sorrow in the Snow" In the anime-only story ''Fushigi Yûgi Eikoden'', Nuriko reincarnates as a young girl named Ko Reishun, with the same super strength as Nuriko.''Fushigi Yûgi Eikoden'' | Japan |- | 1996–1999 | ''[[Outlaw Star]]'' | [[List of Outlaw Star characters#Fred Luo|Fred Lou]] | Gay | Fred is a 20-year-old camp weapons merchant who is known to be flamboyant and openly gay. He has a strong infatuation for the series main protagonist, Gene Starwind, to whom he supplies arms to. | Japan |- | rowspan="6" | 1996–present | rowspan="6" | ''[[Cardcaptor Sakura]]'' and

At the end of the series, Korra and Asami are holding hands and looking into each other's eyes while traveling through a portal right before the ending credits.{{cite episode|title=The Last Stand|series=[[The Legend of Korra]]|network=[[Nickelodeon]]|date=December 19, 2014|season=2|number=226}} The creators later confirmed that the intention of the ending scene was to show Asami and Korra becoming a romantic couple.{{cite web|last1=DiMartino|first1=Michael|url=http://michaeldantedimartino.tumblr.com/post/105916326500/korrasami-confirmed-now-that-korra-and-asamis|title=Korrasami Confirmed|website=michaeldantedimartino.tumblr.com|date=December 22, 2014|accessdate=December 22, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Konietzko|first1=Bryan|url=http://bryankonietzko.tumblr.com/post/105916338157/korrasami-is-canon-you-can-celebrate-it-embrace|title=Korrasami is canon.|website=bryankonietzko.tumblr.com|date=December 22, 2014|accessdate=December 22, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/vf-hollywood/2014/12/korra-series-finale-recap-gay-asami|title=How a Nickelodeon Cartoon Became One of the Most Powerful, Subversive Shows of 2014|publisher=Vanity Fair |date=December 19, 2014|accessdate=December 19, 2014}} In the graphic novel ''The Legend of Korra: Turf Wars'', which is the sequel to the animated series, Korra and Asami are in a relationship. | rowspan="4" | United States |- | [[Asami Sato]] |- | [[List of Avatar: The Last Airbender characters#Water Tribe|Kya]] | Lesbian | Kya's sexuality is not mentioned in the animated series ''The Legend of Korra''. However, in the sequel graphic novel ''The Legend of Korra: Turf Wars'', she is shown to be lesbian and gives advice to Korra and Asami about coming out.{{cite web|url=http://thegeekiary.com/turf-wars-part-1-review/45424|title=Korra and Asami Are Getting Bi: Turf Wars Part 1 Review|work=The Geekiary|date=August 15, 2017}} |- | [[List of Avatar: The Last Airbender characters#Known Avatar incarnations|Kyoshi]] | Bisexual | Avatar Kyoshi is one of the previous reincarnations of [[Aang]] and Korra. She appears in both ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' and ''The Legend of Korra'', but her sexuality is not mentioned in either animated series. In the graphic novel ''The Legend of Korra: Turf Wars'', she is shown to be bisexual. She is described as unable to effect progress towards acceptance of same-sex relationships because the Earth Kingdom is the "slowest to accept change" and "the most militaristically repressive". |- | 2017 | ''[[Spinning (comics)|Spinning]]'' | [[Tillie Walden]] | Lesbian | ''Spinning'' is a graphic novel [[memoir]] by lesbian cartoonist Tillie Walden | United States |} ==See also== {{Portal|LGBT}} * [[List of animated works with LGBT characters]] * [[List of lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender-related films]] * [[Lists of television programs with LGBT characters]] * [[Lists of American television episodes with LGBT themes]] * [[List of animation and graphic art works with polyamorous characters]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{LGBT fiction}} [[Category:LGBT in anime and manga| ]] [[Category:LGBT characters in anime and manga| ]] [[Category:LGBT characters in comics| ]] [[Category:LGBT-related comics| ]] [[Category:Lists of LGBT fictional characters|Graphic art works]] [[Category:LGBT-related lists|Graphic art works]]
